title: Visualizations
text:
LA Airbnb Visualizations
This page shows several key visualizations from our analysis and highlights the enriched variables we created: price per person, amenity flags, annual revenue, and stay type.



Code
import pandas as pd
from pathlib import Path

data_path = Path("C:/Users/adans/OneDrive/Documents/Data Science/Project25/_Final Project - Boston Airbnb/~Final Project - Boston Airbnb/Data/LA_Airbnb_ALL.csv")

df = pd.read_csv(data_path)
# Load LA Airbnb Data
import pandas as pd
from pathlib import Path

data_path = Path("C:/Users/adans/OneDrive/Documents/Data Science/Project25/_Final Project - Boston Airbnb/~Final Project - Boston Airbnb/Data/LA_Airbnb_ALL.csv")

df = pd.read_csv(data_path)

#Inspect the dataset
print("Shape:", df.shape)
print("\nColumn names:\n", df.columns.tolist())
print("\nData types:\n", df.dtypes)

# Missing Values
missing = df.isna().sum().sort_values(ascending=False)
print("\nMissing values per column:\n", missing)

# Top 3 Missing Values
top3_missing = missing.head(3)
print("\nTop 3 columns with the most missingness:\n", top3_missing)

Code
# Clean price — robust handling
df["price_num"] = (
    df["price"]
    .astype(str)
    .str.replace(r"[\$,]", "", regex=True)
    .str.replace(",", "", regex=False)
)

df["price_num"] = pd.to_numeric(df["price_num"], errors="coerce")

# Remove missing/zero prices
df = df[df["price_num"].notna() & (df["price_num"] > 0)]




Code
## Fixed Neighborhood Column ##

df["neighbourhood_cleansed"] = df["neighbourhood_cleansed"].fillna("Unknown")




Code
# -----------------------------------------------------------
# ENRICHMENT 1: NEIGHBORHOOD-LEVEL AGGREGATES
# -----------------------------------------------------------

neigh_stats = (
    df.groupby("neighbourhood_cleansed")
      .agg(
          neighbourhood_avg_price=("price_num", "mean"),
          neighbourhood_avg_reviews=("reviews_per_month", "mean"),
          neighbourhood_listing_count=("id", "count"),
      )
      .reset_index()
)

df = df.merge(neigh_stats, on="neighbourhood_cleansed", how="left")




Code
# -----------------------------------------------------------
# ENRICHMENT 2: HOST-LEVEL AGGREGATES
# -----------------------------------------------------------

host_stats = (
    df.groupby("host_id")
      .agg(
          host_total_listings=("id", "count"),
          host_avg_price=("price_num", "mean"),
          host_avg_reviews=("reviews_per_month", "mean")
      )
      .reset_index()
)

df = df.merge(host_stats, on="host_id", how="left")




Code
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import ast
import plotly.express as px

DATA_PATH = "C:/Users/adans/OneDrive/Documents/Data Science/Project25/_Final Project - Boston Airbnb/~Final Project - Boston Airbnb/Data/LA_Airbnb_ALL.csv"

df = pd.read_csv(DATA_PATH)

# ---- Basic cleaning ----
df["price_num"] = pd.to_numeric(
    df["price"].replace('[\$,]', '', regex=True),
    errors="coerce"
)
df = df[df["price_num"].notna() & (df["accommodates"] > 0)]

# Price per person
df["price_per_person"] = df["price_num"] / df["accommodates"]

# ---- Amenities parsing & flags ----
def parse_amenities(amenities_str):
    if pd.isna(amenities_str):
        return []
    try:
        return ast.literal_eval(amenities_str)
    except Exception:
        return []

df["amenities_list"] = df["amenities"].apply(parse_amenities)
df["amenity_count"] = df["amenities_list"].apply(len)

def has_amenity(amenities_list, keywords):
    joined = " | ".join(amenities_list).lower()
    return any(k.lower() in joined for k in keywords)

df["has_wifi"] = df["amenities_list"].apply(
    lambda a: has_amenity(a, ["wifi", "wi-fi", "internet"])
)
df["has_kitchen"] = df["amenities_list"].apply(
    lambda a: has_amenity(a, ["kitchen"])
)
df["has_pool"] = df["amenities_list"].apply(
    lambda a: has_amenity(a, ["pool"])
)
df["has_free_parking"] = df["amenities_list"].apply(
    lambda a: has_amenity(a, ["free parking", "free street parking"])
)

# ---- Annual revenue (if provided in dataset) ----
if "estimated_revenue_l365d" in df.columns:
    df["annual_revenue"] = df["estimated_revenue_l365d"]
else:
    df["annual_revenue"] = np.nan

# ---- Stay type category ----
def classify_stay(min_nights):
    if pd.isna(min_nights):
        return np.nan
    if min_nights <= 3:
        return "short stay (1–3 nights)"
    elif min_nights <= 14:
        return "medium stay (4–14 nights)"
    else:
        return "long stay (15+ nights)"

df["stay_type"] = df["minimum_nights"].apply(classify_stay)

Code
### Visualization: Price Distribution 
import plotly.express as px
# Filter price range for visualization
price_cap = 500
df_price_plot = df[df['price_num'].between(0, price_cap)]

fig_price_dist = px.histogram(
    df_price_plot,
    x='price_num',
    nbins=50,
    title='Distribution of Nightly Price (0–$500)',
    labels={'price_num': 'Nightly price (USD)'}
)
fig_price_dist.show()


                            
                                            



Nightly Price Distribution (0–$500) The distribution of nightly prices in Los Angeles is right-skewed, with most listings clustered between $80 and $250 per night. This indicates that while LA does have luxury, high-priced properties, they represent a small portion of the market. The majority of Airbnb listings fall into a moderate and affordable price range.



Code
# if we want to show price per person 
price_pp_cap = 250
df_pp_plot = df[df['price_per_person'].between(0, price_pp_cap)]

fig_price_pp = px.histogram(
    df_pp_plot,
    x='price_per_person',
    nbins=50,
    title='Distribution of Nightly Price per Person',
    labels={'price_per_person': 'Price per person (USD)'}
)
fig_price_pp.show()


                            
                                            



Price Per Person Distribution When adjusting for the number of guests accommodated, price-per-person becomes much more concentrated, typically between $20 and $80 per person. This suggests that many higher-priced listings actually offer good value when shared by multiple guests. The distribution also highlights affordability differences between solo



Code
### Visualization: Room type vs price 
df_room_plot = df[df['price_num'].between(0, price_cap)]

fig_room_price = px.box(
    df_room_plot,
    x='room_type',
    y='price_num',
    title='Price by Room Type (0–$500)',
    labels={'room_type': 'Room type', 'price_num': 'Nightly price (USD)'}
)
fig_room_price.show()


                            
                                            



Box Plot — Price by Room Type Entire homes/apartments consistently have the highest price range, with a noticeably larger spread and more extreme high-end listings. Private rooms tend to be moderately priced with lower variability, while shared rooms remain the most budget-friendly and tightly clustered. This pattern reflects the premium placed on privacy and full-property access.



Code
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px

# Convert price to numeric
df["price_num"] = pd.to_numeric(
    df["price"].str.replace('[\$,]', '', regex=True),
    errors="coerce"
)

# Keeps valid price + neighborhood rows
df_valid = df[
    df["price_num"].notna() &
    df["neighbourhood_cleansed"].notna()
]

# Computes average price by neighborhood
neigh_avg_price = (
    df_valid.groupby("neighbourhood_cleansed")["price_num"]
    .mean()
    .reset_index()
)

# Sorts and select the top 15 most expensive
top15 = (
    neigh_avg_price
    .sort_values("price_num", ascending=False)
    .head(15)
)

# Create bar chart
fig = px.bar(
    top15,
    x="neighbourhood_cleansed",
    y="price_num",
    title="Top 15 Most Expensive Neighborhoods in Los Angeles (Average Nightly Price)",
    labels={
        "neighbourhood_cleansed": "Neighborhood",
        "price_num": "Average Nightly Price (USD)"
    }
)

fig.update_layout(
    xaxis_tickangle=-45,
    height=600
)

fig.show()

These neighborhoods cluster around premium coastal or central LA zones. The significant price differences indicate how strongly location influences listing value.

title: Project25
text:
Project Overview
This site summarizes our analysis of Airbnb listings in Los Angeles.
We document our data sources, cleaning, enrichment (price per person, amenities, annual revenue, stay type), and key results.

title: Project25
text:
Data and Methods

Data source: LA Airbnb listings scraped from Airbnb dtaset (LA_Airbnb_ALL.csv)
Raw format: CSV file with one row per listing and columns for price, location, reviews, etc.
Cleaning & enrichment:

Converted nightly price from strings to numeric.
Created price per person = price / accommodates.
Parsed amenities into a list, then flagged WiFi, kitchen, free parking, pool, air conditioning.
Used estimated occupancy to compute annual revenue.
Categorized listings by stay type (short / medium / long) using minimum nights.

Tools: Python, pandas, plotly, ipywidgets, Quarto.

For full details see the visualizations and interactive pages.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: Quarto Basics
text:
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure 1.


Code
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()








Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis
